sub_topic: Finding the slope of a tangent line to a curve
message_1: Given the function f(x) = 2x^3 - 5x^2 + 3x - 1, find the slope of the tangent line to the curve at the point where x = 2.
message_2:
To find the slope of the tangent line to the curve at the point where x = 2, we need to find the derivative of the function f(x) and then evaluate it at x = 2.

The derivative of f(x) with respect to x, denoted as f'(x), can be found using the power rule:

f'(x) = d(2x^3)/dx - d(5x^2)/dx + d(3x)/dx - d(1)/dx

f'(x) = 3(2x^2) - 2(5x) + 3

f'(x) = 6x^2 - 10x + 3

Now, we need to evaluate f'(x) at x = 2:

f'(2) = 6(2)^2 - 10(2) + 3

f'(2) = 6(4) - 20 + 3

f'(2) = 24 - 20 + 3

f'(2) = 7

So, the slope of the tangent line to the curve at the point where x = 2 is 7.
